items.text: What is the main difference between qualitative and quantitative data?

options.text: Qualitative data is numerical and used for mathematical calculations; quantitative data is descriptive and observed.
Quantitative data is descriptive and gathered through interviews; qualitative data is measured and analysed statistically.
Qualitative data is non-numerical and observed through methods like interviews; quantitative data is numerical and used for statistical analysis.
Quantitative data includes opinions and emotions; qualitative data includes test scores and financial figures.

items.text:
Consider the following SQL query:

SELECT First_name, Last_name 
FROM Users 
WHERE Score > 80 
ORDER BY Score ASC

What does the SQL query do?

options.text: Returns all users and displays their scores in descending order.
Returns first and last names of users along with their score if it is less than 80, in ascending order by score.
Updates the scores of users who scored more than 80 and returns the result sorted by scores.
Returns first and last names of users with a score greater than 80, sorted by score in ascending order.

items.text: Within business analytics software, which of the following is a limitation?

options.text: Fewer options for customising data visualisations.
Support for real-time data updates and team collaboration.

items.text: What is the main advantage of using a pivot table in a spreadsheet program?

options.text: It automatically formats the spreadsheet into a visualisation suitable for printing.
It permanently deletes irrelevant data such as redundant data and outliers which results in a reduced file size.
It links the spreadsheet directly to a database such that alterations to the database are reflected in real time within the spreadsheet.
It enables users to efficiently analyse, sort and summarise data from different perspectives.

items.text: In which type of decision support system is a fixed set of rules followed without human involvement?
What is a typical use of sensors and actuators in an intelligent manufacturing system?

options.text: Enabling real-time monitoring and control of machinery

items.text: Why may a development team decide to create a prototype when developing an enterprise system?

options.text: To document research obtained during the development process.
To refine system requirements during the research and planning stage of development.
To test ideas in real world scenarios and obtain feedback.
As a final model of a system that is then distributed commercially to clients.

items.text: Which of the following methods helps maintain data security? (More than one may be selected.)

options.text: Using public Wi-Fi for backup transfers.
Encrypting data when stored and transmitted.
Regularly updating software with security patches.
Keeping all backups in one location for convenience.
Implementing access levels to restrict users' viewing of unnecessary data.
Applying the 3-2-1 backup rule - keep three copies of data, on two different media types, with one copy offsite.
Saving login credentials within the browser for sites that do not use multi-factor authentication.

items.text: Which techniques are used by inference engines? (More than one may be selected.)
Which of the following system development approaches are supported by an iterative methodology? (More than one may be selected.)
Match each description with the best term.

cells.text: A central system for storing large volumes of data from multiple sources
Data that includes a meaningful zero and allows for comparison using multiplication/division
A tool used in spreadsheets to summarise and group large datasets
Technology that records transactions securely in a decentralised, tamper-proof ledger
A type of data that is ordered but does not have consistent intervals between values.
Analysis process that reveals patterns or trends in large datasets

items.text: Match each description with its correct concept.

cells.text: Selecting from datasets based on specific conditions and summarising using trends, averages and clusters.
Uses forecasts and past data trends to help users anticipate future events.
Dashboards that constantly refresh with new data.
Identifying similarities within data enabling the system to learn, make decisions and solve problems.
The ability for users to specify criteria or drill down and the display refreshes immediately.
Data that has no fixed format, such as text and video.

Physical feedback from a system including pressure, vibration and pulses.

items.text: Match the system flowchart symbols displayed with their correct names.
Define Data Bias.

criteria.criterion: Provides a clear and accurate definition of data bias, identifying it as a systematic error where data is not representative of the true population or phenomenon.
Provides a partially correct definition of data bias.

sampleAnswerContentItem.text: Data bias refers to a type of error in which certain elements of a dataset are more heavily weighted or represented than others. This imbalance can lead to inaccurate results or predictions, as the data does not accurately reflect the real-world environment it is supposed to represent. It can arise from various sources, such as biased data collection methods or pre-existing societal prejudices reflected in the data.

title: EC 2025, Q18, Data Lake vs Data Swamp

items.text: Distinguish between a Data Lake and a Data Swamp.

criteria.criterion: Clearly distinguishes between a data lake and a data swamp, highlighting differences in data governance, organisation, and usability.
Provides a good description of either a data lake or a data swamp, with some attempt to distinguish between them.
Provides some relevant information about data lakes or data swamps.

sampleAnswerContentItem.text:
A Data Lake is a centralised repository that stores vast amounts of raw data in its native format. It is well-governed, with metadata and cataloguing that make the data discoverable, accessible, and usable for analysis. It supports various user types, from data scientists to business analysts.

In contrast, a Data Swamp is a deteriorated and unmanaged data lake. It contains a large amount of data, but lacks proper governance, metadata, and organisation. This makes it difficult to find, trust, and use the data for any meaningful analysis. Essentially, a data lake becomes a data swamp when it is poorly managed, turning a valuable asset into an unusable liability.

items.text: A pet shop stores data on pet owners and their pets. An extract of the database schema is reproduced below:

Construct an SQL query that retrieves all records where the Type of pet is a dog. Each row retrieved should include the first name, surname and email of the owner along with the pet’s name and DOB. The results are to be sorted alphabetically by the pet’s name.

parameters.datasetSetupQuery: CREATE TABLE Owners (OwnerID INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, FirstName TEXT, Surname TEXT, Phone TEXT, Email TEXT); CREATE TABLE Pets (PetID INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, Name TEXT, Type TEXT, Breed TEXT, DOB TEXT, OwnerID INTEGER, FOREIGN KEY(OwnerID) REFERENCES Owners(OwnerID)); INSERT INTO Owners VALUES (1, 'John', 'Smith', '0411111111', 'john.s@email.com'), (2, 'Jane', 'Doe', '0422222222', 'jane.d@email.com'); INSERT INTO Pets VALUES (101, 'Buddy', 'Dog', 'Golden Retriever', '2020-05-15', 1), (102, 'Whiskers', 'Cat', 'Siamese', '2021-01-20', 1), (103, 'Max', 'Dog', 'German Shepherd', '2019-11-01', 2);

criteria.criterion: Provides a correct SQL query that fulfills all requirements: selects correct columns, joins tables, filters by pet type, and orders correctly.
Provides a substantially correct query with one minor error (e.g., incorrect ordering, missing one column).
Provides a query that addresses some requirements (e.g., selects from the correct tables but fails to join or filter correctly).
Shows some understanding of SQL syntax.

sampleAnswerContentItem.text:
SELECT 
    O.FirstName, 
    O.Surname, 
    O.Email, 
    P.Name, 
    P.DOB
FROM 
    Owners O
JOIN 
    Pets P ON O.OwnerID = P.OwnerID
WHERE 
    P.Type = 'Dog'
ORDER BY 
    P.Name ASC;

items.text: Consider the following sample data for sales at a pet store:
With reference to the above data, discuss how informatics can support a deeper understanding of the data.

criteria.criterion: Provides a comprehensive discussion of how informatics can be applied to the sample data. Links specific informatics concepts (e.g., data processing, analysis, visualisation) to potential insights (e.g., customer behaviour, sales trends). Justifies the value of these insights for the business.
Explains how informatics could be used to analyse the data, providing relevant examples. Makes a clear link between informatics techniques and business understanding.
Identifies some basic ways informatics could be applied (e.g., calculating totals, creating charts) with limited discussion of the resulting insights.

sampleAnswerContentItem.text:
Informatics, the science of information processing, can transform the raw pet store sales data into actionable business intelligence. Firstly, data can be structured and stored in a database, allowing for efficient querying and processing. This enables aggregation to calculate key metrics, such as total revenue per product or average transaction value.

Secondly, data analysis techniques can uncover hidden patterns. For example, by analysing the 'Product' and 'Pet Type' columns, the store could identify which products are most popular for dogs versus cats. It could also perform a market basket analysis to see if certain items (like 'Dog Leash' and 'Dog Toy') are frequently purchased together, which could inform product placement or promotional bundling.

Finally, data visualisation would make these insights accessible. A dashboard could display sales trends over time using a line chart, compare product category performance with a bar chart, and show the proportion of sales by pet type with a pie chart. This deeper, informatics-driven understanding allows the pet store to make data-informed decisions about inventory management, marketing strategies, and customer engagement, ultimately leading to improved business performance.

items.text: Define data integrity and outline its importance.

criteria.criterion: Correctly defines data integrity and clearly outlines its importance for business operations and decision-making.
Provides a partial definition OR outlines its importance.

sampleAnswerContentItem.text: Data integrity is the maintenance of, and the assurance of, the accuracy and consistency of data over its entire lifecycle. It is important because businesses rely on accurate data for decision-making, operational processes, and maintaining trust with customers. Without data integrity, reports would be flawed, strategies would be based on incorrect information, and the overall reliability of the enterprise system would be compromised.

items.text: Describe how data visualisations assist in understanding and communicating data. Include examples of data visualisations to illustrate your response.

criteria.criterion: Provides a detailed description of how visualisations help in understanding and communication, supported by appropriate examples (e.g., bar charts for comparison, line charts for trends).
Describes how visualisations help, with some relevant examples.
Provides some relevant information, such as naming a type of visualisation.

sampleAnswerContentItem.text:
Data visualisations translate complex datasets into graphical formats, making it easier for the human brain to process information, identify patterns, and understand trends. Instead of analysing rows of numbers, users can quickly grasp key insights.

For example, a bar chart can be used to compare sales figures across different product categories, immediately showing which categories are top performers. A line chart is effective for showing a trend over time, such as monthly revenue changes. A pie chart can illustrate proportions, like the market share of different competitors. By presenting data visually, these tools make complex information accessible and communicable to a wider audience, including stakeholders who may not be data experts.

items.text: The table below is a small extract of the results of a survey of over 4000 children aged 5 to 13 years of age to determine the time spent using a screen during weekdays and during weekends. The data has been anonymised to remove each child’s personal details.

Describe a suitable data visualisation and how it could be produced from the above data. The data visualisation is to display the size and relative differences between weekday and weekend screen time for each age child.

criteria.criterion: Describes a highly suitable visualisation (e.g., clustered bar chart) and clearly explains the steps to produce it from the given data, including defining axes and series.
Describes a suitable visualisation and provides a reasonable explanation of how it could be produced.
Describes a suitable visualisation with limited explanation of its production, or describes the production of a less suitable visualisation.
Identifies a suitable type of visualisation.

sampleAnswerContentItem.text:
A suitable data visualisation would be a clustered bar chart. This chart type is ideal for comparing two categories (Weekday Screen Time and Weekend Screen Time) across a range of discrete groups (Age).

To produce this visualisation using spreadsheet or business analytics software:

  1. Data Selection: Select the three columns of data: 'Age', 'Weekday Screen Time (minutes)', and 'Weekend Screen Time (minutes)'.
  2. Chart Insertion: From the software's chart menu, choose the 'Clustered Bar Chart' (or Column Chart) option.
  3. Axis Configuration: The software should automatically assign 'Age' to the horizontal axis (X-axis). The vertical axis (Y-axis) would represent 'Time in minutes'.
  4. Data Series: Two series of bars would be created for each age group. One series would represent 'Weekday Screen Time', and the other would represent 'Weekend Screen Time'. A legend would be automatically generated to distinguish the two, typically by using different colours for each series.
  5. Titling and Labels: Add a clear title like 'Average Daily Screen Time by Age' and ensure axes are clearly labelled to finalise the chart for presentation.

items.text: Explain how user experience (UX) design principles enhance the effectiveness of data visualisations. You may refer to the following example dashboard to assist your response.

criteria.criterion: Provides a detailed explanation of multiple UX principles and how they enhance data visualisations, effectively linking them to features in the example dashboard.
Explains some UX principles and their application to data visualisations, with some reference to the example.
Identifies one or two UX principles with a basic explanation.

sampleAnswerContentItem.text:
User experience (UX) design principles are crucial for making data visualisations effective because they ensure the information is not only accurate but also accessible, intuitive, and easy to interpret. Key principles include:

  • Clarity and Simplicity: UX design focuses on removing clutter and unnecessary elements. In the example dashboard, there is a clean layout with ample white space, which helps users focus on the key metrics like 'Total Revenue' and 'Profit'. The visualisations themselves are simple (e.g., line chart, bar chart), avoiding overly complex designs that could confuse the user.
  • Visual Hierarchy: This principle involves arranging elements to show their order of importance. The dashboard uses size and placement to draw attention to the most important numbers at the top (the KPIs). This guides the user's eye and helps them understand the most critical information first.
  • Consistency: A consistent design language (e.g., using the same colour for revenue across different charts) reduces cognitive load. Users don't have to re-learn what elements mean, allowing them to interpret the data faster and more accurately.
  • Accessibility: Good UX ensures that visualisations are usable by everyone, including people with disabilities. This includes using colour-blind friendly palettes and providing clear, legible text labels, which enhances the overall usability for all users.

By applying these principles, UX design transforms a data visualisation from a simple chart into an effective communication tool that empowers users to make informed decisions quickly.

title: EC 2025, Q25, Intelligent Systems in Enterprises

items.text: Outline one way an intelligent system uses data to support automated decision-making in an enterprise.

criteria.criterion: Clearly outlines a specific example of an intelligent system, explaining how it uses data to make an automated decision.
Identifies a relevant example with a limited outline.

sampleAnswerContentItem.text: One way is in financial fraud detection. An intelligent system analyses vast amounts of real-time transaction data, looking for patterns that deviate from a customer's normal spending habits. If a transaction is flagged as anomalous (e.g., a large purchase in a foreign country), the system can automatically make the decision to block the transaction and alert the customer, preventing potential fraud without human intervention.

title: EC 2025, Q26, Ethical Issues of Facial Recognition

items.text: Discuss ethical issues associated with the use of cameras, including facial recognition, in retail stores to identify possible security concerns.

criteria.criterion: Discusses multiple relevant ethical issues (e.g., privacy, consent, bias) with clear explanations.
Identifies and briefly discusses one or two ethical issues.
Identifies one relevant ethical issue.

sampleAnswerContentItem.text:
The use of facial recognition in retail stores raises significant ethical issues. A primary concern is privacy and consent; shoppers are often unaware their biometric data is being collected and stored, and they have not given explicit consent for this. This constant surveillance can create a chilling effect on personal freedom.

Another major issue is algorithmic bias. Facial recognition systems have been shown to be less accurate for women and people of colour, which could lead to a higher rate of false positives and wrongful accusations of shoplifting for individuals from these groups. This can result in unfair treatment and discrimination.

Finally, there is the risk of data misuse. The stored biometric data is a valuable target for hackers, and a breach could lead to identity theft. There is also the potential for 'function creep,' where data collected for security is later used for other purposes, like targeted advertising, without the customer's knowledge.

items.text: Analyse how the interaction between the above components contributes to the effectiveness of an enterprise's intelligent security system.

criteria.criterion: Provides a clear analysis of the interaction between all components, explaining how they work together to create an effective, automated security system.
Describes the role of the components and how they link together.
Describes the role of at least two components.
Identifies the role of one component.

sampleAnswerContentItem.text:
The effectiveness of this intelligent security system relies on the seamless interaction between its three core components.

First, the Sensors (e.g., cameras, motion detectors) act as the system's eyes and ears, continuously collecting raw data from the environment. This data is then fed to the AI Analysis component. This is the 'brain' of the system, where machine learning algorithms process the sensor data to identify patterns, anomalies, or specific threats, such as an unauthorised person in a restricted area.

Once the AI analysis identifies a threat, it sends a command to the Control System. This is the 'hands' of the system, which executes an automated response. For example, it might lock doors, trigger an alarm, or notify security personnel. This closed-loop interaction—from data collection by sensors, to interpretation by AI, to action by the control system—allows for a rapid, automated, and intelligent response to security events, far quicker and more consistently than a human-only system could achieve.

items.text:
The following text describes how a mechanic diagnoses an engine that won’t start.

A customer brings in a car that won’t start. The mechanic first checks the battery and finds it’s fully charged, so that’s not the problem. Next, they turn the key and hear the engine crank, which means the starter motor is working. Then, they pull out a spark plug and test it—no spark. That points to an ignition problem. They inspect the ignition coil and find it has failed. After replacing the coil, the mechanic tests the engine again. This time, it starts right up. If it did not start the mechanic would continue by checking for fuel reaching the engine. If no fuel, then they would check various fuel system components. If the engine still fails to start, then they move on to other system such as the computer control system and its various sensors.
Describe the role of each significant component of an expert system that simulates a mechanic diagnosing an engine that won’t start.

criteria.criterion: Thoroughly describes the role of the main components of an expert system (knowledge base, inference engine, user interface) and accurately applies them to the car mechanic scenario.
Describes the role of at least two components and relates them to the scenario.
Identifies one or two components with a basic description.

sampleAnswerContentItem.text:
An expert system simulating a mechanic would consist of several key components:

1. Knowledge Base: This is the core of the system, containing the specialised knowledge of an expert mechanic. It would be populated with facts and rules about car engines. For example:

  • Fact: A battery should have ~12.6 volts.
  • Rule: IF the engine cranks BUT there is no spark, THEN check the ignition system.
  • Rule: IF the ignition coil is faulty, THEN replace the ignition coil.
This database of information allows the system to replicate the diagnostic process described in the text.

2. Inference Engine: This is the reasoning component that applies the rules from the knowledge base to the facts of the specific problem. When a user inputs symptoms (e.g., 'engine won't start', 'engine cranks'), the inference engine uses a technique like forward or backward chaining to logically progress through the diagnostic steps. It would follow the same path as the mechanic: check battery, check starter, check for spark, etc., until it deduces the most likely cause, such as the failed ignition coil.

3. User Interface: This is how a non-expert user (e.g., a junior mechanic or a car owner) interacts with the system. It would present a series of questions ('Is the battery fully charged?', 'Do you hear a cranking sound?') and allow the user to input the answers. At the end of the process, the interface would display the system's diagnosis ('The ignition coil has failed') and the recommended solution ('Replace the coil').

items.text: Outline two tools that support the design and development of enterprise projects.

criteria.criterion: Outlines two distinct and appropriate tools, briefly explaining their function in enterprise projects.
Outlines one appropriate tool.

sampleAnswerContentItem.text:
1. Gantt Charts: These are project management tools used for planning and scheduling. They visually represent the project timeline, tasks, dependencies, and deadlines. This helps project managers track progress, allocate resources, and ensure the project stays on schedule.

2. CASE (Computer-Aided Software Engineering) Tools: These tools automate various stages of the system development life cycle. They can be used to create design diagrams (like DFDs or UML diagrams), generate code from these diagrams, perform testing, and maintain documentation, which improves consistency and efficiency in large enterprise projects.

items.text: Explain how stakeholder feedback can influence the design and development of an enterprise system. In your response, refer to a specific development approach where feedback supports system development.

criteria.criterion: Clearly explains the influence of stakeholder feedback and correctly links it to a specific development approach (e.g., Agile, Prototyping).
Explains the influence of feedback OR identifies a relevant development approach.
Provides some relevant information about feedback or development approaches.

sampleAnswerContentItem.text:
Stakeholder feedback is vital as it ensures the final enterprise system meets the actual needs and expectations of its users and the business. This feedback can influence the system's features, user interface, and workflow. For example, if end-users find a proposed data entry screen confusing, their feedback can lead to a redesign that is more intuitive and efficient, preventing costly rework after the system is launched.

The Agile development approach is built around incorporating feedback. In Agile, the project is broken down into small, iterative cycles called 'sprints'. At the end of each sprint, a working piece of the software is demonstrated to stakeholders. Their feedback is immediately collected and used to prioritise and refine the work for the next sprint. This continuous feedback loop ensures the project evolves in line with stakeholder requirements and delivers maximum business value.

items.text: The decision tree below illustrates how multi-factor authentication is used to manage access to an enterprise system. A one-time password (OTP) is sent as a text message to the user’s mobile phone.
Identify different ways users can authenticate themselves when accessing this system. Justify the reasoning that may be behind the use of this specific strategy and outline any issues you perceive.

criteria.criterion: Correctly identifies the authentication factors, provides a strong justification for the strategy, and outlines relevant issues.
Addresses most parts of the question well, such as identifying factors and providing a justification or outlining issues.
Identifies at least one authentication factor or a relevant issue.

sampleAnswerContentItem.text:
Authentication Methods: Users authenticate themselves using two factors: something they know (their password) and something they have (their mobile phone, to receive the OTP).

Justification: The reasoning behind this Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) strategy is to enhance security. A password alone can be stolen or guessed. By requiring a second factor (the OTP), an attacker would need to compromise both the user's password and have physical access to their phone, which is significantly more difficult. This layered approach greatly reduces the risk of unauthorised access to the enterprise system.

Issues: One issue is reliance on the mobile phone network. If the user has no mobile service, they cannot receive the OTP and will be locked out. Another issue is the security of SMS messages themselves, which are not encrypted and can be intercepted through techniques like SIM-swapping attacks, making this method less secure than using an authenticator app.

items.text:
Maxwell is leading a small enterprise computing project for a new start-up developing a mobile productivity app. His team includes a freelance UX designer in Vietnam, a remote backend developer based in Perth and a local university intern. Discuss how the following factors may affect the development of Maxwell’s project.

  • Offshore development
  • Working remotely
  • Freelance work
  • Enabling the growth of start-ups

criteria.criterion: Provides a thorough discussion of all four factors, identifying both positive and negative effects on the project's development.
Discusses at least two or three of the factors with reasonable detail.
Identifies some relevant effects of one or two of the factors.

sampleAnswerContentItem.text:
Several factors will significantly affect Maxwell's project:

  • Offshore Development: Having a UX designer in Vietnam is an example of offshore development. A major advantage is potential cost savings on salary. However, it introduces challenges like time zone differences, which can delay communication and decision-making. Cultural and language barriers might also affect the clarity of design requirements.
  • Working Remotely: With a developer in Perth, the team is geographically distributed. This offers flexibility and access to a wider talent pool. However, it requires strong project management and communication tools (e.g., Slack, Jira) to ensure collaboration is effective and to avoid team members becoming isolated. Building team cohesion can also be more difficult than with a co-located team.
  • Freelance Work: Using a freelance designer provides specialised skills on a flexible, as-needed basis, which is cost-effective for a start-up. The risk is that the freelancer may have other clients and priorities, potentially affecting their availability and long-term commitment to the project. Clear contracts and deliverables are essential to manage this relationship.
  • Enabling the Growth of Start-ups: This entire team structure is common for start-ups as it allows them to access specialised talent (freelance, offshore) without the high overheads of full-time, local employees. This agility is crucial for a start-up to develop a product quickly and affordably. The inclusion of an intern also provides low-cost support while offering valuable experience, further enabling the start-up's growth on a lean budget.
